title: Discrete Math II
text:
Discrete Math II Functions and Applications (D421)








Note



These exercises are not mines. They are from this Quizlet ¬ª





The Foundations | Logic and Proofs

Chapter 1:


Exercise 1a


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(a)
The statement is a proposition because we know that the statement is true \(T\) (as Boston is the capital of Massachusetts).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.
If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition. If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.


(a) Proposition, \(T\)




Exercise 1b


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.





The statement is a proposition because we know that the statement is false \(F\) (as Tallahassee is the capital of Florida).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(b) Proposition, \(F\)




Exercise 1c


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(c)
The statement is a proposition because we know that the statement is true \(T\) (since 2 added to 3 is equal to 5).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(c) Proposition, \(T\)




Exercise 1d


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(d)
The statement is a proposition because we know that the statement is false \(F\) (since 5 added to 7 is equal to 12, and thus not equal to 10).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(d) Proposition, \(F\)




Exercise 1e


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(e)
The statement is not a proposition, because the statement could be true or could be false (but we do not know which case since \(x\) is unknown).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(e) Not a proposition




Exercise 1f


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(f)
The statement is not a proposition, because it is not a statement that could be true or false.


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(f) Not a proposition






Chapter 2:


Exercise 2a


Step-1Step-2


PART A: This sentence is not a proposition because it is not a declarative sentence.
So it is not possible for this sentence to be true or false.


PART A: not a proposition




Exercise 2b


Step-1Step-2


PART B: This sentence is not a proposition because it is not a declarative sentence.
So it is not possible for this sentence to be true or false.


PART B: not a proposition




Exercise 2c


Step-1Step-2


PART C: This sentence is a proposition because it can either be true or false.
Its truth value is false because black flies exist everywhere.


PART C: proposition, false




Exercise 2d


Step-1Step-2


PART D: This sentence is not a proposition because the value of \(x\) is not given.
So it is not possible for this sentence to be true or false.


PART D: not a proposition




Exercise 2e


Step-1Step-2


PART E: This sentence is a proposition because it can either be true or false.
Its truth value is false because the moon is not made from green cheese.


PART E: proposition, false




Exercise 2f


Step-1Step-2


PART F: This sentence is not a proposition because the value of \(n\) is not given.
So it is not possible for this sentence to be true or false.


PART F: not a proposition






Chapter 3


Exercise 3


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


(a)

\(\text{ Linda is younger than Sanjay. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Linda is not younger than Sanjay. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Linda is older or the same age as Sanjay.


(b)

\(\text{ Mei makes more money than Isabella. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Mei does not make more money than Isabella. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Mei makes less money or the same amount of money than Isabella.


(c)

\(\text{ Moshe is taller than Monica. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Moshe is not taller than Monica. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Moshe is shorter or the same height as Monica.


(d)

\(\text{ Abby is richer than Ricardo. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Abby is not richer than Ricardo. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Abby is poorer or equally rich to Ricardo.



(a) Linda is not younger than Sanjay.
(b) Mei does not make more money than Isabella.
(c) Moshe is not taller than Monica.
(d) Abby is not richer than Ricardo.







Chapter 4:


Exercise 4


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4


(a)

\(\text{ Janice has more Facebook friends than Juan. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Janice does not have more Facebook friends than Juan. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Janice has less Facebook friends or the same number of Facebook friends as Juan.


(b)

\(\text{ Quincy is smarter than Venkat. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Quincy is not smarter than Venkat. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Quincy is dumber or equally intelligent as Venkat.


(c)

\(\text{ Zelda drives more miles to school than Paola. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Zelda does not drive more miles to school than Paola. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Zelda drives less miles or the same number of miles to school than Paola.


(d)

\(\text{ Brianna sleeps longer than Gloria. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Brianna does not sleep longer than Gloria. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Brianna sleeps less or the same amount than Gloria.

Results

(a) Janice does not have more Facebook friends than Juan.
(b) Quincy is not smarter than Venkat.
(c) Zelda does not drive more miles to school than Paola.
(d) Brianna does not sleep longer than Gloria.








Chapter 5:


Exercise 5a


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(a) The opposite of a statement can be obtained by adding ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the given statement. The opposite of Mei having an MP3 player is that Mei does not have an MP3 player.


(a) Mei does not have an MP3 player.




Exercise 5b


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(b) The opposite of no pollution in New Jersey is that there is pollution in New Jersey.


(b) There is pollution in New Jersey.




Exercise 5c


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(c) The opposite of an equality \((=)\) is a difference \(\text{(‚â†)   2+1 ‚â† 3 }\)


(c) \(2+1 ‚â† 3\)




Exercise 5d


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(d) The opposite of a statement can be obtained by adding ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the given statement: The summer in Maine is not (hot and sunny).


(d) The summer in Maine is not (hot and sunny).

Chapter 8:


Exercise 8a


Step-1Results


A.  Smartphone B has 288 MB RAM, which is the most out of the other two phones.



A. True





Exercise 8b


Step-1Results


B.  Either the ROM has to be greater or the resolution has to be greater. The resolution is greater in this example so it is true.



B. True





Exercise 8c


Step-1Results


C.  It is false because the resolution is larger in Smartphone A.



C. False





Exercise 8d


Step-1Results


D.  It may have more RAM and ROM, but Smartphone B‚Äôs resolution is less making the statement false.



D. False





Exercise 8e


Step-1Results


E.  It is a biconditional statement which is F - T making the statement false.



E. False







Chapter 9:


Exercise 9a


Step-1Results


a. This proposition is false because Quixote Media had less annual revenue than Acme Computer ($111 billion < $138 billion).



a. False





Exercise 9b


Step-1Results


b.  This proposition is true because both statements are true.



b. True





Exercise 9c


Step-1Results


c.¬† This proposition is true because Quixote Media had the largest net profit.
Note: Since this is an \(V\) statement, either statement being true makes the proposition true.



c.¬†True





Exercise 9d


Step-1Results


d.¬† This proposition is true because Acme Computer had the largest revenue.
Note: this is an \(‚áí\) proposition. Even though Quixote did not have the smallest net profit (hypothesis), the conclusion still holds.



d.¬†True





Exercise 9e


Step-1Results


e.  This proposition is true because in both directions the conclusions hold true.



e. True







Chapter 10


Exercise 10a


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)
\(p ‚àß q: \text{p and q}\)
\(p ‚Üí q: \text{if p, then q}\)
\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


I did not buy a lottery ticket this week.





(a) I did not buy a lottery ticket this week.





Exercise 10b


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)

\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


I bought a lottery ticket this week or I won the million dollar jackpot.





(b) I bought a lottery ticket this week or I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

If I bought a lottery ticket this week, then I won the million dollar jackpot.





(c) If I bought a lottery ticket this week, then I won the million-dollar jackpot.





Exercise 10d


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Exercise 10f


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Exercise 10g


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)

Exercise 10h


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)

SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


I did not buy a lottery ticket this week and I did not win the million dollar jackpot.





(h) I did not buy a lottery ticket this week or, I bought a lottery ticket this week and won the million dollar jackpot.

crumbs: Discrete Math II Functions and Applications

title: DSA I
text:
Characteristics of Algorithms






Names






Finiteness
An algorithm must always have a finite number of steps before it ends. When the operation is finished, it must have a defined endpoint or output and not enter an endless loop.
Definiteness
An algorithm needs to have exact definitions for each step. Clear and straightforward directions ensure that every step is understood and can be taken easily.
Input
An algorithm requires one or more inputs. The values that are first supplied to the algorithm before its processing are known as inputs. These inputs come from a predetermined range of acceptable values.
Output
One or more outputs must be produced by an algorithm. The output is the outcome of the algorithm after every step has been completed. The relationship between the input and the result should be clear.
Effectiveness
An algorithm‚Äôs stages must be sufficiently straightforward to be carried out in a finite time utilizing fundamental operations. With the resources at hand, every operation in the algorithm should be doable and practicable.
Generality
Rather than being limited to a single particular case, an algorithm should be able to solve a group of issues. It should offer a generic fix that manages a variety of inputs inside a predetermined range or domain.





Factors of an Algorithm






Factors






**Modularity**
This feature was perfectly designed for the algorithm if you are given a problem and break it down into small-small modules or small-small steps, which is a basic definition of an algorithm.
Correctness
An algorithm‚Äôs correctness is defined as when the given inputs produce the desired output, indicating that the algorithm was designed correctly. An algorithm‚Äôs analysis has been completed correctly.
Maintainability
It means that the algorithm should be designed in a straightforward, structured way so that when you redefine the algorithm, no significant changes are made to the algorithm.
Functionality
It takes into account various logical steps to solve a real-world problem.
Robustness
Robustness refers to an algorithm‚Äôs ability to define your problem clearly.
User-friendly
If the algorithm is difficult to understand, the designer will not explain it to the programmer.
Simplicity
If an algorithm is simple, it is simple to understand.
**Extensibility**
Your algorithm should be extensible if another algorithm designer or programmer wants to use it.






Types of Algorithms


Type-1Type-2Type-3Type-4













Brute Force Algorithm
A straightforward approach that exhaustively tries all possible solutions, suitable for small problem instances but may become impractical for larger ones due to its high time complexity.











Recursive Algorithm
A method that breaks a problem into smaller, similar subproblems and repeatedly applies itself to solve them until reaching a base case, making it effective for tasks with recursive structures.











Encryption Algorithm
Utilized to transform data into a secure, unreadable form using cryptographic techniques, ensuring confidentiality and privacy in digital communications and transactions.













Backtracking Algorithm
A trial-and-error technique used to explore potential solutions by undoing choices when they lead to an incorrect outcome, commonly employed in puzzles and optimization problems.











Searching Algorithm
Designed to find a specific target within a data set, enabling efficient retrieval of information from sorted or unsorted collections.











Sorting Algorithm
Aimed at arranging elements in a specific order, like numerical or alphabetical, to enhance data organization and retrieval.






















Hashing Algorithm
Converts data into a fixed-size hash value, enabling rapid data access and retrieval in hash tables, commonly used in databases and password storage.











Divide & Conquer Algorithm
Breaks a complex problem into smaller subproblems, solves them independently, and then combines their solutions to address the original problem effectively.











Greedy Algorithm
Makes locally optimal choices at each step in the hope of finding a global optimum, useful for optimization problems but may not always lead to the best solution.













Dynamic Programming Algorithm
Stores and reuses intermediate results to avoid redundant computations, enhancing the efficiency of solving complex problems.











Randomized Algorithm
Utilizes randomness in its steps to achieve a solution, often used in situations where an approximate or probabilistic answer suffices.






Recursive Algorithms


Algorithms
Recursive algorithms are a fundamental concept in computer science, particularly in the study of data structures and algorithms. A recursive algorithm is one that solves a problem by breaking it down into smaller instances of the same problem, which it then solves in the same way. This process continues until the problem is reduced to a base case, which is solved directly without further recursion.



Key Concepts


Base CaseRecursive CaseStack


This is the condition under which the recursion stops. It represents the simplest instance of the problem, which can be solved directly without further recursion.


This is the part of the algorithm that breaks the problem down into smaller instances of the same problem and then calls the algorithm recursively on these smaller instances.


Each recursive call is placed on the system call stack. When the base case is reached, the stack begins to unwind as each instance of the function returns its result.






Factorial Calculation

The factorial of a number n (denoted as n!) is a classic example of a recursive algorithm. The factorial is defined as:

O! = 1 (Base Case)
N! = n * (n-1)! For n > O (Recursive Case)


CodeLogicPros/ConsUsage



def factorial(n):
    if n == 0:  # Base Case
        return 1
    else:  # Recursive Case
        return n * factorial(n - 1)



How It Works:

Base Case: When n is 0, the function returns 1.
Recursive Case: For any other value of n, the function calls itself with n‚àí1 and multiplies the result by n.

For example, calling factorial(3) would work as follows:

factorial(3) calls factorial(2)
factorial(2) calls factorial(1)
factorial(1) calls factorial(0)
factorial(0) returns 1, then:
factorial(1) returns 1 * 1 = 1
factorial(2) returns 2 * 1 = 2
factorial(3) returns 3 * 2 = 6



Advantages of Recursion

Simplicity: Recursive solutions are often more elegant and easier to understand than their iterative counterparts.
Direct Translation: Some problems are naturally recursive, like tree traversals, making recursion the most straightforward approach.

Disadvantages of Recursion

Performance: Recursive algorithms can be less efficient due to the overhead of multiple function calls and potential stack overflow issues for deep recursion.
Memory Usage: Recursion can consume more memory because each function call adds a new frame to the call stack.



When to Use Recursion - When a problem can naturally be divided into similar sub-problems (e.g., tree traversal, searching algorithms like binary search). - When the recursive solution is significantly simpler or more intuitive than an iterative one.






Linear & Binary Search

Linear search and binary search are two fundamental algorithms used to search for an element in a collection, like an array or a list. However, they differ significantly in how they approach the search and their efficiency.


Linear Search


ConceptStepsUsage



Linear search is the simplest search algorithm.
It works by sequentially checking each element of the array or list until the target element is found or the end of the collection is reached.



Algorithm:

Start from the first element of the array.
Compare the current element with the target element.
If they match, return the index of the element.
If they don‚Äôt match, move to the next element and repeat the process.
If the target element is not found by the end of the array, return a ‚Äúnot found‚Äù indication.

Time Complexity: \(O(n)\), where n is the number of elements in the array. This is because in the worst case, the algorithm may need to check every element in the array.


When to Use:

When the array or list is small.
When the array is unsorted.
When simplicity is more important than performance.


def linear_search(arr, target):
    for i in range(len(arr)):
        if arr[i] == target:
            return i
    return -1  # Return -1 if the element is not found







Binary Search


ConceptStepsUsageCompare



Binary search is much more efficient than linear search but requires the array or list to be sorted.
It works by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half. If the target value is less than the middle element, the search continues in the left half, otherwise in the right half.



Algorithm:

Start with two pointers, one at the beginning (low) and one at the end (high) of the sorted array.
Find the middle element of the current interval.
Compare the middle element with the target:

If they match, return the index of the middle element.
If the target is less than the middle element, repeat the search on the left half.
If the target is greater, repeat the search on the right half.

If the interval becomes invalid (low > high), return a ‚Äúnot found‚Äù indication.

Time Complexity: \(\text{O(log‚Å° n)}\), where n is the number of elements in the array. This logarithmic time complexity makes binary search significantly faster than linear search for large data sets.


When to Use:

When the array or list is sorted.
When the array is large and efficiency is crucial.


def binary_search(arr, target):
    low = 0
    high = len(arr) - 1

    while low <= high:
        mid = (low + high) // 2
        if arr[mid] == target:
            return mid
        elif arr[mid] < target:
            low = mid + 1
        else:
            high = mid - 1

    return -1  # Return -1 if the element is not found



Comparison

Efficiency: Binary search is faster than linear search, especially for large data sets, but it requires the array to be sorted.
Simplicity: Linear search is simpler to implement and doesn‚Äôt require the array to be sorted, making it more versatile for smaller or unsorted data sets.
Use Cases:

Linear Search: Suitable for small or unsorted collections where the simplicity of the algorithm outweighs the need for speed.
Binary Search: Ideal for large, sorted collections where performance is a priority.








Step-by-Step Guide


ArraysSetup1st Iteration2nd Iteration


Figuring out the array elements that correspond to the mid-values in the first and second iterations of A binary search
\(\text{ arr = {45, 77, 89, 90, 94, 99, 100} }\) and \(\text{key = 100}\)



The array arr is {45, 77, 89, 90, 94, 99, 100}.
The key to find is 100.
Initialize two pointers: low (start of the array) and high (end of the array).




Calculate the middle index mid using the formula: mid = (low + high) / 2
Check the value at arr[mid].
Compare arr[mid] with the key:

If arr[mid] is less than key, update low to mid + 1.
If arr[mid] is greater than key, update high to mid - 1.
If arr[mid] is equal to key, you have found the key (though you won‚Äôt need a second iteration in this case).





Repeat the calculation for mid with the updated low and high values.
Again, compare arr[mid] with the key and update low or high accordingly.








Searching Algorithms

Linear Search



LogicUsageStates



Concept: As discussed earlier, linear search involves checking each element in a list or array sequentially until the target element is found or the end of the collection is reached.
Time Complexity: \(O(n)\), where n is the number of elements.




Use Case: Best used when the list is small or unsorted.
Distinct Characteristics:

Simple, sequential search.
Checks each element one by one.
Works on both sorted and unsorted data.





Linear Search Worst, Average and Best

**Best Case:** $O(1)$ ‚Äî The target element is the first element.
**Average Case:** $O(n)$ ‚Äî The target element is somewhere in the middle or not in the array.
**Worst Case:** $O(n)$ ‚Äî The target element is the last element or not present.








Binary Search



LogicUsageStates



Concept: Binary search operates on a sorted list. It repeatedly divides the search interval in half until the target element is found or the interval is empty.
Time Complexity: \(\text{O(log‚Å° n)}\)




Use Case: Ideal for large, sorted datasets.
Distinct Characteristics:

Requires a sorted array.
Divides the search interval in half repeatedly.
Efficient, logarithmic time complexity.





Binary Search Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(O(1)\) ‚Äî The target element is the middle element.
Average Case: \(\text{O(log‚Å° n)}\) ‚Äî The target element is not immediately found but within the sorted array.
Worst Case: \(\text{O(log‚Å° n)}\) ‚Äî The target element is at the extreme ends or not present.








Interpolation Search



LogicUsageStates



Concept: Similar to binary search but works on uniformly distributed data. It estimates the position of the target element based on the value.
Time Complexity: O(log ‚Å°log ‚Å°n) in the best case, \(O(n)\) in the worst case.




Use Case: Effective when the data is uniformly distributed.




Interpolation Search Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(O(1)\) ‚Äî The target element is exactly where the interpolation suggests.
Average Case: \(\text{O(log ‚Å°log‚Å° n)}\) ‚Äî Uniformly distributed data.
Worst Case: \(O(n)\) ‚Äî Highly skewed data distribution or worst interpolation.








DFS/BFS



LogicUsageStates



Concept: Used primarily in graph and tree data structures. Depth-First Search (DFS) explores as far as possible along one branch before backtracking, while Breadth-First Search (BFS) explores all neighbors at the present depth before moving on to nodes at the next depth level.
Time Complexity: \(\text{O(V + E)}\), where V is the number of vertices and E is the number of edges.




Use Case: Useful for searching nodes in graphs and trees.




(DFS)

Best Case: \(O(1)\) ‚Äî The target node is found immediately.
Average Case: \(\text{O(V + E)}\)‚Äî Typically when all nodes and edges must be explored.
Worst Case: \(\text{O(V + E)}\) ‚Äî The target node is the last one discovered.

(BFS)

Best Case: \(O(1)\) ‚Äî The target node is the root or the first node checked.
Average Case: \(\text{O(V + E)}\) ‚Äî All nodes and edges need to be explored.
Worst Case: \(\text{O(V + E)}\) ‚Äî The target node is the last one explored.









Sorting Algorithms
Sorting algorithms organize data in a particular order (usually ascending or descending). This makes searching and other operations more efficient.


Bubble Sort



UsageDescriptorStatesTips



Use Case: Simple but inefficient for large datasets. Best used for educational purposes or small lists.




Distinct Characteristics:

Repeatedly swaps adjacent elements if they are in the wrong order.
Simple, but inefficient for large datasets.
‚ÄúBubbles‚Äù the largest element to the end of the list.





Bubble Sort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(O(n)\) ‚Äî The array is already sorted (with an optimized version that stops early).
Average Case: \(O(n^2)\) ‚Äî Average case with random elements.
Worst Case: \(O(n^2)\) ‚Äî The array is sorted in reverse order.





Bubble: Look for something that swaps so the result can ‚Äúbubble‚Äù to the top. (Swap, Exchange)







Selection Sort



UsageDescriptorStatesTips



Use Case: Inefficient for large lists, but useful when memory writes are more expensive than comparisons.




Distinct Characteristics:

Finds the minimum element and swaps it with the first unsorted element.
Reduces the problem size by one in each iteration.
Always performs \(O(n^2)\) comparisons, regardless of input.





Selection Sort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(O(n^2)\) ‚Äî Selection sort does not improve with better input, always \(O(n^2)\).
Average Case: \(O(n^2)\) ‚Äî Average case with random elements.
Worst Case: \(O(n^2)\) ‚Äî Selection sort is insensitive to input order.





Selection: Look for code that repeatedly finds the minimum (or maximum) element and moves it to the beginning (or end) of the list. (Select minimum, Swap with start)







Insertion Sort



UsageDescriptorStatesTips



Use Case: Good for small or nearly sorted lists.




Distinct Characteristics:

Builds a sorted list one element at a time.
Efficient for small or nearly sorted datasets.
Shifts elements to make space for the current element.





Insertion Sort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(O(n)\) ‚Äî The array is already sorted.
Average Case: \(O(n^2)\) ‚Äî Average case with random elements.
Worst Case: \(O(n^2)\) ‚Äî The array is sorted in reverse order.





Insertion: Look for code that builds a sorted portion of the list one element at a time by inserting each new element into its correct position within the already-sorted part. (Insert, Shift Element)







Merge Sort



UsageDescriptorStatesTips



Use Case: Efficient and stable; good for large datasets.




Distinct Characteristics:

Divides the list into halves, sorts each half, and then merges them.
Stable and efficient for large datasets.
Requires additional space for merging.





Merge Sort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°log‚Å° n)}\) ‚Äî Merge sort‚Äôs time complexity is the same in all cases.
Average Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°log‚Å° n)}\).
Worst Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°log‚Å° n)}\).





Merge: Look for something that continually splits a list in half. (Merge, Split)







Quicksort



UsageDescriptorStatesTips



Use Case: Often faster in practice than merge sort but less stable.




Distinct Characteristics:

Selects a ‚Äúpivot‚Äù element and partitions the array around it.
Recursively sorts the partitions.
Efficient, but can degrade to \(O(n^2)\) if poor pivot selection occurs.





Quicksort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°log‚Å° n)}\) ‚Äî The pivot splits the array into two nearly equal halves.
Average Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°log‚Å° n)}\) ‚Äî Average case with random pivots.
Worst Case: \(O(n^2)\) ‚Äî The pivot is always the smallest or largest element, leading to unbalanced partitions.





Quicksort: Look for the keywords ‚Äúpivot‚Äù and/or ‚Äúsplit‚Äù. (Pivot, Split)







Heap Sort



UsageDescriptorStatesTips



Use Case: Useful when memory usage is a concern as it‚Äôs an in-place algorithm.




Distinct Characteristics:

Utilizes a binary heap data structure.
Builds a max-heap and repeatedly extracts the maximum element.
Efficient and in-place, but not stable.





Heap Sort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°log‚Å° n)}\) ‚Äî Heap sort‚Äôs time complexity is the same in all cases.
Average Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°log‚Å° n)}\).
Worst Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°log‚Å° n)}\).





Heap Sort: Look for code that uses a heap data structure to repeatedly extract the maximum (or minimum) element and rebuilds the heap. (Heapify, Extract Max, Build Heap)







Counting Sort



UsageDescriptorStates



Use Case: Efficient for sorting integers or other items with a small range of possible values.




Distinct Characteristics:

Non-comparative sorting.
Counts occurrences of each element and uses this information to place elements.
Efficient for small ranges of integers.





Counting Sort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°+ k) - k}\) is the range of the input.
Average Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°+ k)}\).
Worst Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°+ k)}\).








Radix Sort



UsageDescriptorStatesTips



Use Case: Effective for sorting large numbers or strings with a fixed length.




Distinct Characteristics:

Sorts numbers by processing individual digits.
Non-comparative, stable, and efficient for specific data types.
Often combined with counting sort.





Radix Sort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°* k)}\) ‚Äî k is the number of digits in the largest number.
Average Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°* k)}\).
Worst Case: \(\text{O(n ‚Å°* k)}\).





Radix Sort: Look for code that sorts numbers based on their individual digits, starting from the least significant digit (LSD) or the most significant digit (MSD). (Count, Frequency, Sum)







Bucket Sort



UsageDescriptorStatesTips



Use Case: Good for uniformly distributed data.




Distinct Characteristics:

Distributes elements into buckets and sorts each bucket individually.
Efficient when the input is uniformly distributed.
Often combined with another sorting algorithm like insertion sort.





Bucket Sort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(\text{O(n + k)}\) ‚Äî k is the number of buckets; assumes uniform distribution.
Average Case: \(\text{O(n + k)}\).
Worst Case: \(O(n^2)\) ‚Äî All elements end up in one bucket (degenerate case).





Bucket: Look for something that distributes the values into ‚Äúbuckets‚Äù where they are individually sorted. (Bucket)







Shell Sort



DescriptorStatesTips



Distinct Characteristics:

Generalization of insertion sort with a gap sequence.
Sorts elements far apart and gradually reduces the gap.
Efficient for medium-sized datasets.
Time Complexity: Depends on the gap sequence; commonly \(\text{O(n3/2)}\).





Shell Sort Worst, Average and Best

Best Case: \(\text{O(n log n)}\) ‚Äî Occurs when the array is already sorted or nearly sorted, especially when using a good gap sequence like the Knuth sequence.
Average Case: \(O(n^(3/2))\) or \(O(n^1.5)\) ‚Äî Highly dependent on the gap sequence used. With commonly used sequences like the Knuth sequence, the average-case complexity is approximately \(O(n^1.5)\).
Worst Case: \({O(n^2)}\) ‚Äî Can degrade to \({O(n^2)}\), particularly with poorly chosen gap sequences like the original Shell sequence (where the gaps are halved each time)





Shell Sort: Look for code that sorts elements at specific intervals and gradually reduces the interval until it performs a final insertion sort. (Gap, Interval)








Summary








Searching & Sorting Algorithms






Linear Search: Simple, sequential; \(O(n)\).
Binary Search: Sorted data, divide and conquer; \(\text{O(log n)}\).
Bubble Sort: Swaps, bubbles up; \(O(n^2)\).
Selection Sort: Finds minimum, swaps; \(O(n^2)\).
Insertion Sort: Builds sorted list, shifts; \(O(n^2)\), \(O(n)\) best case.
Merge Sort: Divide and conquer, merge; \(\text{O(n log n)}\).
Quick Sort: Pivot, partition; \(\text{O(n log n)}\) average, \(O(n^2)\) worst case.
Heap Sort: Max-heap, extract max; \(\text{O(n log n)}\).
Counting Sort: Counts occurrences, non-comparative; \(\text{O(n + k)}\).
Radix Sort: Sorts by digits, non-comparative; \(O(nk)\).
Bucket Sort: Distributes into buckets, sorts; \(\text{O(n + k)}\).
Shell Sort: Gap sequence, insertion-like; \(O(n^3/2)\).










Key Observations






Bubble Sort, Selection Sort, and Insertion Sort: These are simple but inefficient for large datasets, especially in the worst case.
Merge Sort and Heap Sort: Stable and consistent in performance, regardless of the input.
Quick Sort: Very efficient on average but can degrade to \(O(n^2)\) in the worst case without proper pivot selection.
Counting Sort, Radix Sort, and Bucket Sort: Efficient for specific types of data (e.g., integers within a fixed range) but less versatile.










Choosing the Right Algorithm






Small datasets: Simpler algorithms like bubble sort, selection sort, or insertion sort might suffice.
Large datasets: More efficient algorithms like merge sort, quick sort, or heap sort are preferred.
Sorted data: Algorithms like insertion sort can be very efficient.
Special conditions: Use counting sort, radix sort, or bucket sort if the data is within a certain range or has other specific properties.








Big O Notation
What is Big O Notation?

Big O Notation: It provides an upper bound on the time or space complexity of an algorithm, representing the worst-case scenario. It‚Äôs a way to describe the efficiency of an algorithm as the input size grows towards infinity.

Why Use Big O Notation?

Comparing Algorithms: It allows us to compare the efficiency of different algorithms independently of hardware or other environmental factors.
Scalability: It helps us understand how an algorithm will perform as the size of the input data grows.



O Notations

title: Scripting & Programming
Data Structures and Algorithms I
text:
Characteristics of Algorithms






Names





Finiteness
An algorithm must always have a finite number of steps before it ends. When the operation is finished, it must have a defined endpoint or output and not enter an endless loop.
Definiteness
An algorithm needs to have exact definitions for each step. Clear and straightforward directions ensure that every step is understood and can be taken easily.
Input
An algorithm requires one or more inputs. The values that are first supplied to the algorithm before its processing are known as inputs. These inputs come from a predetermined range of acceptable values.
Output
One or more outputs must be produced by an algorithm. The output is the outcome of the algorithm after every step has been completed. The relationship between the input and the result should be clear.
Effectiveness
An algorithm‚Äôs stages must be sufficiently straightforward to be carried out in a finite time utilizing fundamental operations. With the resources at hand, every operation in the algorithm should be doable and practicable.
Generality
Rather than being limited to a single particular case, an algorithm should be able to solve a group of issues. It should offer a generic fix that manages a variety of inputs inside a predetermined range or domain.
